Graphical abstract Selective catalytic reduction of NOx by CO (CO-SCR) in the presence of O2 is challenging because in this process CO is prone to being oxidized by O2, thus inhibiting NOx reduction by CO. Furthermore, SO2 typically leads to the deactivation of the CO-SCR catalyst. Herein, a significant promoting effect of SO2 on Ir/SiO2 catalyst for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2 is reported. In-situ X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis showed that SO2 does not affect the chemical nature of Ir0 under reaction conditions. However, SO2 can be oxidized to sulfate and deposit on the catalyst surface. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis demonstrated that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the CO + O2 reaction, thus leaving more CO available to reduce NOx over the active Ir0 sites. As a result, the reduction of NOx is remarkably promoted even in the presence of O2 and SO2. Keywords NOx reduction CO-SCR Ir/SiO2 catalyst SO2 effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) from both mobile and stationary sources can cause serious environmental issues, such as haze and acid rain [1]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx by the appropriate reducing agent has proven to be an effective method for addressing these issues, and the commonly used reducing agent is NH3 [2,3]. However, many problems are encountered in the NH3-SCR technology, such as NH3 slip, fouling of air heaters, and the complexity of the after-treatment system [4]. As emissions regulations become increasingly stringent, the control of multiple pollutants remains to be one of the challenging tasks. Recently, selective catalytic reduction of NOx by CO(CO-SCR) has attracted more and more attention because in this process NOx and CO can be removed simultaneously [5–7]. A variety of catalysts, including noble metal [8–13] and metal oxide [14–16] catalysts, have been investigated for the CO-SCR of NOx. Although some metal oxide catalysts are active for the reduction of NOx by CO in the absence of O2, they are no longer effective for the removal of NOx in the presence of O2 due to the competitive reaction between NO + CO and CO + O2 [15,16]. The latter reaction leads to the consumption of CO, leaving little CO available to reduce NOx. Taylor and Schlatter [17] investigated the noble metal (Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ir) catalysts for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2, and found that Ir catalyst is active for the removal of NOx. Wang et al. [18] also reported that Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst is more active than other noble catalysts (Pt, Pd, and Rh/ZSM-5) for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of 2 % O2. Previous research has shown that Ir-based catalyst is the most active for the CO-SCR reaction in the presence of O2. Since O2 and SO2 are typically co-present in actual exhaust, the catalytic performance of the CO-SCR catalyst in the presence of both O2 and SO2 has been investigated [10,19]. For Ir/Al2O3 catalyst, the presence of SO2 led to a decrease of the activity, and the poisoning effect is irreversible [20]. The formation of Al2(SO4)3 on the catalyst was proposed to be responsible for the deactivation. The recent research by Ji et al. [21] has shown that IrW-WO3/KIT-6 catalyst exhibited high tolerance to SO2, with only a slight decrease in activity in the presence of 50 ppm SO2. Haneda et al. [22,23] reported that the presence of 20 ppm SO2 can promote the CO-SCR reaction over Ir/SiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, when the SO2 was removed from the reaction stream, the promoting effect was almost completely lost [22]. However, the promoting effect of SO2 is not yet clear. Therefore, revealing the enhancement mechanism is crucial for the development of highly efficient CO-SCR catalyst. In the present study, we have fabricated nanosphere SiO2 supported Ir catalyst and investigated its catalytic performance for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2. Interestingly, a remarkable promoting effect of SO2 was observed, and the enhancement was still maintained even when SO2 was excluded from the reaction gas. Based on the in situ X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), the cause of the promotional effect of SO2 on Ir/SiO2 catalyst has been revealed. This research provides novel insights into the mechanistic role of SO2 on Ir/SiO2 catalyst for CO-SCR of NOx. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ethanol (≥99.7 %), NH3·H2O solution (25 ∼ 28 %) and tetraethyl orthosilic (TEOS) (≥98.5 %) are purchased from Beijing Tongguang Fine Chemicals Co., Ltd. IrCl3(55.47 % Ir, Aladdin) was used in the catalyst preparation. The gas used were 2.03 % NO/He (certified mixture grade), 3.98 % CO/He (certified mixture grade), 3.96 % H2/He (certified mixture grade), 1493 ppm SO2/He (certified mixture grade), He (99.999 %) and O2 (99.999 %), and all were supplied by Beijing Haipu Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation SiO2 nanosphere was prepared by the Stöber method [24]. After mixing 7.67 mol of ethanol, 300 ml of NH3·H2O solution (containing 4.01 mol NH3), and 1.66 mol of deionized water, 0.16 mol TEOS was added to the solution. Subsequently, the mixture was refluxed at 60 °C for 2 h. The obtained turbid suspension was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and dried at 120 °C for 10 h. Then SiO2 nanosphere was obtained. Ir/SiO2 catalyst with a Ir loading of 0.5 wt% was prepared by the impregnation method. In a typical synthesis, 1 g SiO2 nanosphere was impregnated with 1.49 ml 1.74 mol/L IrCl3 solution. Then the mixture was dried at 120 °C for 10 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 4 h. 2.3 Catalytic performance measurement The catalytic performance was evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with the reactant gas consisting of 1000 ppm NO, 6000 ppm CO, 5 % O2, 10–50 ppm SO2 (when used) and He (the balance gas). The concentrations of these gases are similar to those in the previous research [22]. 0.2 g catalyst (40–60 meshes) is used, and the total flow rate is 100 ml/min, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20000 h−1. The catalyst was first pretreated in a 4 % H2/He flow at 400 ℃ for 1 h before each test, unless otherwise stated. The catalyst after the reaction in the presence of 20 ppm SO2 was denoted as the used Ir/SiO2(S) catalyst. The concentrations of the gases were measured online by chemiluminescence NO/NO2 analyzer (Thermo Scientific, model 42i-HL) and a FITR spectrometer (Gasmet FTIR DX4000). The NOx conversion, CO conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated using the following equations. (1) N O x c o n v e r s i o n = N O x in - N O x out [ N O x ] in × 100 % (2) CO conversion = [ C O ] in - [ C O ] out [ C O ] in × 100 % (3) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = [ N O x ] in - [ N O x ] out - 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ N O x ] in - [ N O x ] out × 100 % The reaction rate (k) and turnover frequency (TOF) for the CO-SCR of NOx were obtained using the differential reactor over which the NOx conversion was kept below 15 %. Before the kinetic experiments, the absence of mass transport resistances was checked (supporting information). (4) k ( μ m o l / g · s ) = F Y NOx X NOx m cat (5) TOF ( s - 1 ) = 192.2 F Y NOx X NOx LD m cat where F is the total molar flow rate (mol/s), YNOx is the molar fraction of NOx in the feed, XNOx is the conversion of NOx, L is the actual weight loading of Ir, D is the dispersion of Ir, mcat is the weight of catalyst (g) used in the reaction, and 192.2 is the molar mass of Ir (g/mol). 2.4 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption–desorption was carried out on a Quantachrome Nova automated gas sorption system. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE system with Cu Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscope(SEM) images were taken by a Hitachi S-4800 instrument. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on JEM-2100 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on the electron spectrometer (VG Scientific, ESCALab220i-XL) with Al Kα radiation and C 1 s signal (284.8 eV) as the reference. Temperature programmed desorption of NOx (NOx-TPD) was conducted using the same procedure as described in our previous work [25]. Ir/SiO2 was first pretreated in a 4 % H2/He flow at 400 ℃ for 1 h prior to the SEM, TEM, XPS, and NOx-TPD characterizations. CO pulse chemisorption was conducted using AutoChem1 ΙΙ 2920, in which the doses of CO to the sample were measured after being treated in 4 %H2/He at 400 °C for 1 h. The content of Ir was determined by a PerkinElmer Optima 5300 DV inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry. In situ XAFS data were measured at the beam lines 1W1B of Beijing Synchrotron radiation facility (BSRF) with an electron beam energy of 2.2 GeV and a current of 50 mA. A Si (111) double crystal monochromator was used for energy scan. In situ XAFS cell is a proportional integral derivative (PID) controlled heating reactor equipped with polyimide windows. The cell can be fed with different gases, and the outer shell is fitted with water cooling to protect the polyimide window. The detailed in situ XAFS experiment procedure was as follows: 0.4 g powdered sample was pressed into wafer, whose thickness and diameter are 1.1 mm and 13 mm, respectively, and loaded into an in situ reaction cell. Then the sample was subjected to a 4 % H2/He flow at 400 ℃ for 1 h, and subsequently, the spectra was taken and denoted as H2-400 ℃. Afterward, the temperature was decreased to 225 ℃, and the reaction gas (1000 ppm NO, 6000 ppm CO, 5 % O2, and He as the balance gas) was fed and maintained at this temperature for 1 h, then the spectra was taken and designated as NO + CO + O2-225 ℃. Next, 20 ppm SO2 was added to the reaction gas and maintained for 1 h, after which the spectra were taken and designated as NO + CO + O2 + SO2-225 ℃. Subsequently, SO2 was excluded from the reaction gas and maintained for 1 h, and then the spectra were taken and designated as NO + CO + O2-225 ℃. The resultant data were analyzed by Athena from Ifeffit 0.9.20 software package (Demeter © Bruce Ravel). The catalysts were also studied by in situ DRIFTS experiment under different reaction conditions, and the IR spectra were collected on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer with a highly sensitive MCT detector. Prior to the experiment, the sample was pre-treated in a 4 % H2/He flow at 400 ℃ for 1 h, then purging with He and take the background spectrum at the desired temperature. The spectra were obtained by subtracting the corresponding background. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Basic catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Physical structure analysis The physical properties of SiO2, Ir/SiO2, and the used Ir/SiO2(S) are presented in Table S1. It can be seen that the specific surface areas of these samples are low. The SEM analysis illustrated that Ir/SiO2 catalyst exhibits a nanosphere morphology with a diameter of about 400–500 nm (Fig. 1 a). The TEM image (Fig. 1b) showed that Ir particles are dispersed on the SiO2 nanosphere. From the high resolution TEM (HRTEM) image, it can be seen that a lattice spacing of 0.22 nm is mainly present, which is assigned to the plane of Ir (111) [26,27]. The particle size of Ir on the used Ir/SiO2(S) catalyst (8.3 nm) is only slightly larger than that on the fresh Ir/SiO2 catalyst (7.4 nm) (Fig. 2 ), which indicates the catalyst is stable in the presence of SO2. The XRD patterns of SiO2 and Ir/SiO2 are shown in Fig. 3 . The strong peak centered at 21.8° can be assigned to amorphous SiO2 [28]. The diffraction peak assigned to Ir species is absent, indicating that Ir is highly dispersed on the SiO2 support, or the loading amount was lower than the limit of XRD detection. 3.1.2 XPS analysis XPS analysis was conducted to elucidate the chemical nature of the fresh Ir/SiO2 and used Ir/SiO2(S) catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 4 a, Ir 4f XPS spectra can be fitted into four peaks centered at ∼ 60.9, 61.8, 63.8 and 64.6 eV, which are ascribed to Ir0 (60.9 and 63.8 eV) and Irδ+ (61.8 and 64.6 eV) [29,30], respectively. On the fresh and used Ir/SiO2(S), both the peaks assigned to metallic Ir0 and Irδ+ can be observed. Over the used Ir/SiO2(S) the ratio of Ir0 (Ir0/(Ir0 + Irδ+)) is 57.1 %, which is similar to that over the fresh Ir/SiO2 (58.8 %). This indicates that after the reaction in the presence of SO2, the chemical nature of Ir is little changed. In addition, a weak peak of S 2p XPS spectra at 167.9 eV, which is ascribed to the sulphate species [31], can be observed over the used Ir/SiO2(S) (Fig. 4b). This demonstrated that surface sulfate species can be formed on Ir/SiO2 during the CO-SCR reaction in the presence of SO2. 3.1.3 NOx-TPD NOx-TPD profiles of Ir/SiO2 and used Ir/SiO2(S) catalysts are illustrated in Figure S1. It is noted that the desorption curves are similar for both catalysts, and all the NOx was desorbed in the form of NO. This indicates that NO2 is rarely formed over the catalysts. The first desorption peak is at about 160 ℃, and the second broad peak is located between 250 and 450 ℃. The amount of desorbed NOx from Ir/SiO2 is 5.13 μmol gcat -1, which is slightly higher than that from the used Ir/SiO2(S) catalyst (4.77 μmol gcat -1). This suggests that the presence of trace sulfate slightly inhibits the adsorption of NOx, and the used Ir/SiO2(S) catalyst still retains good NOx adsorption capacity. 3.2 CO-SCR performance Fig. 5 shows the effect of SO2 on the catalytic performance of Ir/SiO2 catalyst in the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2. As presented in Fig. 5a, the activity of Ir/SiO2 catalyst is very poor in the absence of SO2, with a maximum NOx conversion of 20 % at 175 ℃. Intriguingly, the introduction of 10 ppm SO2 results in a significant enhancement in its activity. A maximum NOx conversion of 93 % can be achieved at 225 ℃, and the activity temperature window is broadened. Further increasing the concentration of feeding SO2, the activity is little changed. This suggests that the presence of SO2 can exert a significant promoting effect on the CO-SCR of NOx. Different from the NOx conversion, CO conversion was suppressed in the presence of SO2. CO was totally converted at 175 ℃ in the absence of SO2. However, due to the presence of SO2, only approximately 15–18 % CO conversion is obtained at this temperature. Furthermore, the complete CO conversion temperature shifts to 225 °C regardless of the concentration of SO2 (Fig. 5b). It is worth noting that the peak NOx conversion temperature is in accordance with the temperature of CO complete conversion. This indicates the conversion of NOx is closely related to the CO conversion. CO conversion was inhibited but the NOx conversion was promoted due to the addition of SO2, suggesting that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the CO + O2 reaction while promoting the NOx + CO reaction. Although the N2 selectivity is decreased between 200 and 300 ℃ in the presence of SO2, the selectivity is still high (>88 %) (Fig. 5c). Figure S2 compares the specific reaction rate of NOx reduction over Ir/SiO2 catalyst at different temperatures. As indicated, the presence of SO2 exhibited a promoting effect on the reaction rate. Moreover, the turnover frequencies (TOFs) have also been calculated based on the Ir surface sites (Table S1). As illustrated in Fig. 6 , the TOFs in the presence of SO2 are noticeably higher than those in the absence of SO2, and the TOF does not vary with the SO2 level. This maybe because the formed sulfate is little changed, even when the SO2 concentration is varied, and the trace sulfate would inhibit the CO + O2 reaction. Therefore, more CO is available for the NOx reduction. This demonstrates that the presence of CO is crucial for the NOx reduction in the presence of O2. Fig. 7 illustrates the temperature dependence of CO-SCR reaction rate over Ir/SiO2 in the absence and presence of SO2. It is clear that the apparent activation energy (Ea) in the presence of SO2 (66 kJ/mol) is lower than that in the absence of SO2 (119 kJ/mol). The lower Ea means the reduction of NOx proceeds more easily due to the presence of SO2. The CO-SCR activities of the fresh Ir/SiO2 and used Ir/SiO2(S) catalysts in the presence and absence of SO2 were also compared. As shown in Figure S3, the used Ir/SiO2(S) catalyst still exhibited much higher activity than the fresh catalyst in the absence of SO2. Moreover, the activity of the used catalyst is similar in both the absence and presence of SO2, indicating that the formed sulfate still present on the used Ir/SiO2(S) catalyst contributes to its high activity even in the absence of SO2. Therefore, the promoting effect of SO2 is irreversible. The response of NOx conversion and CO conversion to the intermittent feeding of SO2 over Ir/SiO2 catalyst at 200 °C is exhibited in Fig. 8 . Upon the introduction of 20 ppm SO2 into the reaction stream, NOx conversion is significantly improved from 15 % to 65 %. As the reaction proceeded, NOx conversion is little changed, indicating the activity of the catalyst is stable in the presence of SO2. After excluding SO2 from the reactant, NOx conversion is only slightly decreased. In contrast to NOx conversion, CO conversion was decreased due to the presence of SO2. This indicates that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the CO + O2 reaction, leading to more CO available for reducing NOx and thereby promoting the NOx reduction. Both the results shown in Figure S3 and Fig. 8 demonstrate that the promoting effect of SO2 is irreversible. This is different from Haneda’s report [22], in which the promoting effect is lost after the removal of SO2. The concentration of O2 plays an important role in the CO-SCR of NOx. Therefore, the effect of O2 on the catalytic performance of Ir/SiO2 catalyst has been investigated. As shown in Fig. 9 , increasing O2 concentration from 2 % to 5 % leads to a decrease of NOx conversion, and the NOx conversion was further decreased as the O2 concentration is increased to 10 %. With increasing the O2 concentration, the CO + O2 reaction was promoted (Figure S4), thus resulting in the decrease of the NOx conversion. N2 selectivity remains similar in the presence of 2 % and 5 % O2, and it decreases slightly as the O2 concentration is increased to 10 % (Figure S4). The catalytic performance comparison of different Ir-based catalysts is shown in Table 1 . The TOFs of Ir/SiO2 are significantly higher than those of the previously reported Ir-based catalysts [21]. Therefore, the results from the present work are promising. 3.3 Advanced characterization 3.3.1 In situ XAFS analysis The intensity of the white line in the Ir L3 XANES spectra is dependent on the density of unoccupied states and is often used as the fingerprint for the changes in the valence of Ir [21,32,33]. In order to better reveal the effect of SO2 on the chemical nature of Ir, in situ Ir L3 XANES spectra were recorded under different gas flows, and the evolution of the spectra is illustrated in Fig. 10 . As the catalyst is reduced in H2 at 400 ℃ for 1 h, the intensity of the white line is lower than that of IrO2 but higher than that of Ir foil, indicating the co-existence of Ir0 and Irδ+. After that the temperature was decreased to 225 ℃, and the gas was switched to the reaction gas (1000 ppm NO + 6000 ppm CO + 5 % O2) and kept for 1 h. Interestingly, the intensity of the white line is little changed, indicating that the chemical nature of Ir is stable even in the reaction gas. Subsequently, 20 ppm SO2 was introduced into the gas and maintained for 1 h, and no change in the intensity of the white line is observed, which suggests the presence of SO2 exerts no effect on the chemical nature of Ir. As the gas was switched to the original reaction gas again, the white line is not changed either. These phenomena demonstrated that in the reaction gas (NO + CO + O2) the chemical nature of Ir was not oxidized due to the presence of O2, and the presence of SO2 exerts no effect on the chemical nature. This is in accordance with the XPS analysis. 3.3.2 In situ DRIFTS studies In order to reveal the interaction between SO2 and Ir/SiO2 catalyst, the adsorption of SO2 + O2 at 225 ℃ was studied by in situ DRIFTS, and the results are shown in Fig. 11 . After the catalyst was exposed to SO2 + O2, a peak at 3648 cm−1 can be observed, which is ascribed to the sulfate species [34]. Meanwhile, negative peaks at 3726 and 3697 cm−1 appeared. This indicates that the formed sulfate species bonds the H atom in the surface hydroxyl groups on SiO2 through one or two atoms of sulfate [35,36]. Therefore, SO2 could be first oxidized to SO3 on Ir sites, followed by the spillover of SO3 to the support and formation of SO4 2- species in hydroxyl positions on SiO2 [37]. The presence of SO2 can inhibit the oxidation of CO (Fig. 5b). Therefore, the effect of SO2 on the adsorption of CO + O2 was further investigated by in situ DRIFTS. As illustrated in Fig. 12 a, when only CO was fed for 30 min, three peaks assigned to gas phase CO (2175 cm−1) [38], CO adsorbed on Irδ+ (2115 cm−1) [39,40], and linear CO adsorbed on Ir0 (2073 cm−1) [22,41] can be observed on Ir/SiO2 catalyst. When O2 was introduced into the reaction gas for 30 min, the peak assigned to linear CO on Ir0 is significantly decreased, and the other two peaks disappear. This suggests that the adsorbed CO and gaseous CO can be oxidized by O2. As SO2 was added to the gas, the peaks related to the gas phase CO and CO adsorbed on Irδ+ appeared again in 2 min, and the peak ascribed to linear CO on Ir0 is increased noticeably. As the exposure time is prolonged to 30 min, the intensities of these three peaks rarely changed. Even after SO2 was removed from the CO + O2 + SO2 (Fig. 12b), the peaks attributed to CO remain unchanged. This fact suggests that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the oxidation of CO, leaving more CO available for reducing NOx. And the inhibiting effect on CO oxidation still can be observed even after SO2 was excluded. This could be due to the presence of formed sulfate on the catalyst surface, which can prevent the reaction of CO + O2. This also explain why the promoting effect of SO2 is irreversible (Figure S3 and Fig. 8). Fig. 13 illustrates in situ DRIFT spectra over Ir/SiO2 catalyst at different temperatures. After the reaction of NO + CO + O2 for 1 h (Fig. 13a and b), a weak peak assigned to gas phase CO is observed at 175 ℃, and this peak disappears above 200 ℃. The intensity of the peak ascribed monodentate nitrate (1283 cm−1) [42,43] is rarely changed with increasing temperature from 175 to 275 ℃. The noise signals appear at 1300–1440 cm−1, which are caused by SiO2 [44]. Whereas under the reaction of NO + CO + O2 + SO2 (Fig. 13c and d), the peaks assigned to gas phase CO, CO adsorbed on Irδ+ and linear CO adsorbed on Ir0 can be observed, while the peak related to the monodentate nitrate is absent. This further demonstrated that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the oxidation of CO by O2, leaving more CO available for the reaction with the adsorbed monodentate nitrate. For the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2, there are two competitive reactions (NOx + CO and CO + O2). The CO + O2 reaction is preferred, consuming the reducing agent CO and leaving only a limited amount to reduce NOx, resulting in low NOx conversion. Therefore, inhibiting the CO + O2 reaction while promoting the NOx + CO reaction is a challenging task. Herein, the presence of SO2 leads to a significant enhancement in the CO-SCR activity. In situ XANES spectra combined with XPS analysis demonstrated that after reducing Ir/SiO2 at 400 ℃, both Ir0 and Irδ+ are present, and they remained stable in their chemical nature even in the reaction gas of CO + NO + O2 or CO + NO + O2 + SO2. The presence of CO could play an important role in keeping the chemical nature of Ir. Similar to this report, Al2O3-SiO2 support can maintain the metallic or less oxidized Pt or Pd species even at high concentrations of O2 [45,46]. Haneda et al. [22] report that Ir0 is almost completely oxidized in the CO-SCR of NOx in the absence of SO2, whereas the existed SO2 can create Ir0 species thus showing a promoting effect. In the present study, different cause for the promoting effect of SO2 has been revealed, and the promotional mechanism of SO2 is illustrated in Scheme 1 . In the presence of O2, CO + O2 reaction is dominant. Most of CO is consumed by O2, leaving little CO available for reducing NOx, thus suppressing the NO + CO reaction. Once SO2 is introduced, on one hand, SO2 is of “oxygen scavenging” ability [47,48], it can consume the active O species used to oxidize CO. On the other hand, SO2 was oxidized by O and form sulfate, which can limit the transfer of O2 and the CO oxidation [49–51]. Therefore, the oxidation of CO was suppressed, allowing more CO to be available for the reduction of NOx over the active Ir0 sites [22]. As a result, the CO-SCR of NOx process has been facilitated remarkably. 4 Conclusions Nanosphere SiO2 supported Ir catalyst has been investigated for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2. Ir/SiO2 catalyst is inactive for the reduction of NOx in the absence of SO2, with a maximum NOx conversion of only about 20 %. However, the CO-SCR activity is remarkably improved in the presence of SO2, with a maximum NOx conversion of 93 % achievable at 225 ℃. The activity rarely changed as the concentration of SO2 was further increased from 10 ppm to 20 or 50 ppm. In situ XAFS and XPS analysis revealed that SO2 does not affect the chemical nature of Ir0 under the reaction conditions. In situ DRIFTS analysis demonstrated that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the CO + O2 reaction, which is caused by the formed sulfate in the presence of SO2. Therefore, more remaining CO can reduce NOx over the active Ir0 sites, thus leading to enhanced CO-SCR activity. The present research provides new insight into the promotional effect SO2 on the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2. coredata.dc:description: Selective catalytic reduction of NOx by CO (CO-SCR) in the presence of O2 is challenging because in this process CO is prone to being oxidized by O2, thus inhibiting NOx reduction by CO. Furthermore, SO2 typically leads to the deactivation of the CO-SCR catalyst. Herein, a significant promoting effect of SO2 on Ir/SiO2 catalyst for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2 is reported. In-situ X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (XAFS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis showed that SO2 does not affect the chemical nature of Ir0 under reaction conditions. However, SO2 can be oxidized to sulfate and deposit on the catalyst surface. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis demonstrated that the presence of SO2 can inhibit the CO + O2 reaction, thus leaving more CO available to reduce NOx over the active Ir0 sites. As a result, the reduction of NOx is remarkably promoted even in the presence of O2 and SO2.
coredata.dc:title: Unveiling the significant promoting effect of SO2 on Ir/SiO2 catalyst for the CO-SCR of NOx in the presence of O2
